title: 106_s2837
content: The Credit Cost Reduction Act of 2000, also known as the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, has been amended to exempt communications related to legal proceedings from the definition of communication. This exemption includes actions taken in accordance with the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, state court rules, or nonjudicial foreclosure. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act has been amended to allow collection activities to continue during the 30-day period after initial notice, unless the consumer requests cessation. Liability for noncompliance is also addressed. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act has been amended to clarify limitations on class action awards and to allow attorney's fees for enforcing civil liability. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act has been amended to include rules applicable to actions under the title, allowing for attorney's fees for the plaintiff and disallowance of certain fees after refusal of a settlement offer. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act now allows for attorney's fees for the plaintiff in actions under the title. If a settlement offer is rejected and the final judgment is equal to or less than the offer, the consumer may not recover costs for attorney's fees incurred after the offer rejection. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act has been amended to consider factors such as the frequency and persistence of noncompliance by debt collectors in actions under subsection (a)(2)(A). Additionally, the Act now includes provisions regarding bona fide errors by debt collectors. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act has been amended to include provisions regarding bona fide errors by debt collectors, allowing them to rely on rules of civil procedure to show good faith compliance and avoid liability in certain actions. SEC. 5. MORTGAGE SERVICERS' REGULATORY BURDEN RELIEF. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to include a Mortgage servicer exemption for servicers of federally related mortgage loans secured by first liens. Servicers exempt from certain requirements if debt collection is secondary to servicing mortgage loans. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to exempt servicers of federally related mortgage loans secured by first liens from certain requirements. Servicers must provide consumers with a notice of their right to receive a validation statement at least 30 days before any acceleration of the debt. If requested, the servicer must provide the validation statement within 10 days. The servicer is not required to delay foreclosure or other actions on a federally related mortgage loan if they receive a validation request from the consumer. Servicers can have a separate office for handling validation requests. The servicer is not liable for inaccurate third-party charges in validation statements for a federally related mortgage loan. Definitions are provided in this section. In this section, definitions are provided for terms like 'federally related mortgage loan', 'qualified validation request', and 'servicer'. The text provides definitions for terms related to servicing and validation statements under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. It also includes a clerical amendment to the table of sections. "818. Mortgage servicer exemption."
